name: Chapter 9: Selecting an AWS Region
description: Flashcards that explain how to choose an AWS Region based on compliance, latency, service availability, and pricing.

cards.front: Your company is based in the UK and local laws require all customer data to stay within the country. How should you select an AWS Region?
cards.back: Choose the AWS London Region to meet compliance requirements that restrict data to within national boundaries.
cards.example: A UK pizza shop must store customer info in London due to legal restrictions, not in nearby EU locations.
cards.mnemonic: Stay legal. Pick the Region your laws allow.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: Adherence to legal or regulatory standards requiring data to be processed or stored in specific locations.
A separate geographic area where AWS clusters data centers to serve users.

cards.front: Why would you choose an AWS Region close to your customers even if your business operates elsewhere?
cards.back: To reduce latency and improve user experience by serving content from a Region geographically closer to the customer base.
cards.example: A Washington DC pizza shop opens a Singapore branch to deliver hot pizzas faster to fans in Asia.
cards.mnemonic: Hot pizza needs a local oven.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: The delay before a transfer of data begins following an instruction.
The practice of deploying resources close to end users to reduce response time and improve performance.

cards.front: What should you check before deploying a new AWS service in a specific Region?
cards.back: Ensure that the service is available in that Region, as not all AWS services are launched globally at the same time.
cards.example: You want to use Amazon Braket, but it's only available in a few Regions like Oregon—not all Regions support it.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: The presence or absence of specific AWS services in a given Region.

cards.front: Why might the same AWS service cost more in one Region than another?
cards.back: Because pricing varies by Region due to local infrastructure, taxes, labor, and operational costs.
cards.example: Running a pizza shop in São Paulo costs more than in Portland due to higher local expenses—same for AWS services.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: Variation in AWS service costs between Regions due to local operating conditions.
